images.copyright: Juvenile Banggai cardinalfish with sea anemone, Lembeh Strait, North Sulawesi, Indonesia (© Constantinos Petrinos/NPL/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Stripe-tacular!
images.caption: Banggai cardinalfish with sea anemone
images.desc: Dive deep beneath the waves surrounding the Banggai Islands in Indonesia and meet the Banggai cardinalfish. Cardinalfish can grow over 7 centimetres and have tiny shimmery bodies with black vertical stripes and white-edged fins, which help them disguise. Unlike some finned creatures that migrate long distances, these pint-sized fish inhabit a small world, rarely straying far from their local reefs.

og.title: Banggai cardinalfish with sea anemone
og.desc: Dive deep beneath the waves surrounding the Banggai Islands in Indonesia and meet the Banggai cardinalfish. Cardinalfish can grow over…

images.copyright: The Fire Wave, a rock formation in Valley of Fire State Park, Nevada (© Clint Losee/Tandem Stills + Motion)
images.title: Hot spot for a cool photo
images.caption: Valley of Fire State Park, Nevada, USA
images.desc: Amid the arid expanse of the Mojave Desert in Nevada, US, lies the natural grandeur of the Valley of Fire State Park. This park, which stretches across 186 square kilometres, is named after the fiery red Aztec Sandstone, an Early Jurassic geological formation made up of ancient sand dunes. The park's highlight, Fire Wave, is a geological marvel that appears like a frozen wave with its red, pink and white stripes.
images.bsTitle: Hot spot for a cool photo

og.title: Valley of Fire State Park, Nevada, USA

images.copyright: Volcanic crater lakes on Kelimutu, Flores, Indonesia (© Shane P. White/Minden Pictures)
images.title: The views will blue your mind
images.caption: Kelimutu, Flores, Indonesia
images.desc: You might have seen lakes with some unique colours before, but Indonesian island of Flores, with its volcano Kelimutu, may steal the show. Home to three lakes, each with its own hue and folklore, this natural wonder attracts travellers seeking an otherworldly experience. Volcanic vents deep within the Earth release steam and gas, which alter the lakes' mineral compositions, causing reactions that transform their appearance periodically.
images.bsTitle: The views will blue your mind

images.copyright: Aerial view of a roundabout in Dhaka, Bangladesh (© Azim Khan Ronnie/Amazing Aerial Agency)
images.title: Dark night, city lights
images.caption: Dhaka, Bangladesh
images.desc: Cultural opulence, bustling economy and spirited locals—welcome to Dhaka in Bangladesh! This megacity on the Ganges Delta, home to over 10.2 million people, is one of the most densely populated cities on the planet. Once known as Jahangirnagar after ruling emperor Jahangir, Dhaka was the provincial capital of the Mughal Empire for 75 years in total.

images.title: Getting lost in the mist
images.caption: Amazon rainforest, Brazil
images.desc: Fresh air, lush foliage, rustling leaves and the calls of thousands of species of animals and birds—welcome to the Amazon rainforest. Covering over 5,438,000 square kilometres, this ecological treasure in South America extends its branches across nine nations—Brazil, Peru, Colombia, Bolivia, Ecuador, French Guiana, Guyana, Suriname and Venezuela.

og.desc: Fresh air, lush foliage, rustling leaves and the calls of thousands of species of animals and birds—welcome to the Amazon rainforest…

images.copyright: Rishikesh at night (© Andrey Khrobostov/Alamy Stock Photo)
images.title: Meditate and navigate
images.caption: International Day of Yoga
images.desc: Grab your mat and find your flow—it's International Day of Yoga! Celebrated around the world on June 21 each year, this day was proposed to the United Nations by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The UN adopted the day in 2014 after the initiative received unanimous support from 177 countries in the General Assembly.

og.desc: Grab your mat and find your flow—it's International Day of Yoga! Celebrated around the world on June 21 each year, this day was proposed to…

images.copyright: Kokino, an ancient megalithic observatory, North Macedonia (© stoimilov/Shutterstock)
images.title: Sunrise on the Solstice
images.caption: Summer solstice
images.desc: It's that time of year again—the daylight stretches long into the evening hours! This phenomenon, known as the summer solstice, occurs when one of the Earth's poles is most inclined toward the sun. Today's image features the Kokino megalithic observatory, which is part of the Kokino archaeological site in North Macedonia. It is believed that Kokino observatory marked the position of the sun during summer and winter solstices, as well as the equinox, and consists of two platforms. A stone block on the upper platform of the observatory indicates the summer solstice sunrise direction when seen from a seat on the lower platform. So, when in North Macedonia, don't miss out on experiencing this ancient astronomical wonder!

og.title: Summer solstice
og.desc: It's that time of year again—the daylight stretches long into the evening hours! This phenomenon, known as the summer solstice, occurs when…

images.copyright: Reticulated giraffe mother greeting calf, Lewa Wildlife Conservancy, Kenya (© Sean Crane/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Spot-on connection
images.caption: Reticulated giraffe mother greeting calf in Kenya
images.desc: Featured here are reticulated giraffes, found mostly in Kenya, but also in parts of Somalia and Ethiopia. Giraffes have fascinated travellers from around the world for a long time. These animals were viewed as symbols of status and treasured as pets among royalty. Their coats feature large, polygonal-shaped spots that extend onto the lower legs, tail and face. Unfortunately, only around 16,000 reticulated giraffes remain in the wild, less than half of the approximately 36,000 recorded in the 1980s. Nevertheless, recent years have observed a promising trend in northern Kenya, where populations are rebounding thanks to places like the Lewa Wildlife Conservancy. So, let's pledge to protect these creatures and their habitats.
